prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CO(3-2) in z~3 SMGs
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Observe CO(3-2) in two z~3 SMGs (ALESS 49.1, 57.1)

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
From our entire sample of >100 ALMA-identified, spectroscopically-observed SMGs, we have identified exactly four sources which have redshifts that allow them to be observed both in low-J CO and [CII] with ALMA. Because the sources have all been precisely-located with ALMA in Cycle 0, we can be sure that the counterparts are correct. This is critical, as our Cycle 0 program demonstrated that a large fraction of single-dish SMG counterparts identified as 'reliable' by statistical associations are actually incorrect (Hodge et al. 2013a).
The robust spectroscopic redshifts of our sources place them at z~2 and z~3, concurrent with the epoch of galaxy assembly and the peak era of activity for obscured starbursts. All four sources will have their CO(3-2) emission (345 GHz rest-frame) redshifted into Band 3. Using the most extended Cycle 2 configuration (C34-7), we reach an angular resolution of ~0.45", allowing us to resolve the molecular gas reservoirs on scales of ~3 kpc (Fig. 3).
For the z~3 sources, we observe the CO(3-2) in the lower sideband, setting up three additional basebands to observe the continuum. The sources are sufficiently close in redshift that we use only one tuning. We use the lowest-resolution FDM mode and average over 8 channels to maintain adequate resolution while keeping the data rate reasonable.
To estimate the required sensitivity for the sources, we use the latest L_FIR-L_CO relation from Bothwell et al. (2012). The relation has some scatter, partly due to the fact that different high-redshift galaxies have been observed at different transitions, and partly inherent to the nature of the individual galaxies. Swinbank et al. (2013) recently used our Cycle 0 870um data, along with 24um and radio imaging, to deblend the Herschel/SPIRE imaging and therefore extract robust far-infrared fluxes for these sources. The far-infrared luminosities of these four sources therefore range from L_FIR ~ 4-7 X 10^12 L_sol, implying CO luminosities of L_CO ~ 2-4 X 10^10 K km/s pc^2. Using the relation L_CO = 3.25 X 10^7*S_CO*delta(v)*D^2*nu^-2*(1+z)^3 (Solomon et al. 1997), this translates into S_CO*delta(v) ~ 0.6-1.2 Jy km/s, or S_CO ~ 1.2-2.4 mJy assuming a typical CO(3-2) line width (FWHM) of 500 km/s. These values are in line with typical values measured for SMGs (Bothwell et al. 2012).
With 50 MHz channels (~125 km/s, sufficient to better-than-Nyquist sample the line), we aim for an average S/N of at least 5sigma per channel in order to well-determine the line profile and so set our sensitivity limit as 0.23 mJy based on the weakest source in our sample. Given the significant uncertainties in all of these estimates (for example, fixing the dust emissivity to beta=2, as proposed by Magnelli et al., would more than double the predicted CO flux for some sources), we choose to retain a constant noise limit over all four targets. We therefore estimate an on-source exposure time of ~28 min per target. Including the current Cycle 2 calibrations and overheads, this becomes ~60 min per target, or ~4 hours total for all four SMGs.
Even in these relatively short exposures, we expect to obtain high-significance detections of the CO(3-2) emission from these luminous SMGs (~20sigma integrated over the line). Given our requested resolution, we expect to resolve the sources over ~4-5 beams, resulting in ~4-5sigma detections per beam. This combination of resolution and S/N will allow us to identify spatial offsets down to </~1 kpc scales between distinct velocity components within these systems.
We also expect to obtain ~8sigma detections of the rest-frame ~870um continuum in these sources, which, in combination with the existing Band 7 continuum and proposed Band 8/9 continuum, will allow us to better constrain the slope of the long-wavelength spectral energy distribution (and hence the contribution from cold dust).

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CO(3-2) in ALESS 67.1
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Observe CO(3-2) in the z~2 SMG ALESS 67.1

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
From our entire sample of >100 ALMA-identified, spectroscopically-observed SMGs, we have identified exactly four sources which have redshifts that allow them to be observed both in low-J CO and [CII] with ALMA. Because the sources have all been precisely-located with ALMA in Cycle 0, we can be sure that the counterparts are correct. This is critical, as our Cycle 0 program demonstrated that a large fraction of single-dish SMG counterparts identified as 'reliable' by statistical associations are actually incorrect (Hodge et al. 2013a).
The robust spectroscopic redshifts of our sources place them at z~2 and z~3, concurrent with the epoch of galaxy assembly and the peak era of activity for obscured starbursts. All four sources will have their CO(3-2) emission (345 GHz rest-frame) redshifted into Band 3. Using the most extended Cycle 2 configuration (C34-7), we reach an angular resolution of ~0.45", allowing us to resolve the molecular gas reservoirs on scales of ~3 kpc (Fig. 3).
For the z~2 sources, we observe the CO(3-2) in the upper sideband, setting up three additional basebands to observe the continuum. The sources require different tunings which we have placed in separate science goals. We use the lowest-resolution FDM mode and average over 8 channels to maintain adequate resolution while keeping the data rate reasonable.
To estimate the required sensitivity for the sources, we use the latest L_FIR-L_CO relation from Bothwell et al. (2012). The relation has some scatter, partly due to the fact that different high-redshift galaxies have been observed at different transitions, and partly inherent to the nature of the individual galaxies. Swinbank et al. (2013) recently used our Cycle 0 870um data, along with 24um and radio imaging, to deblend the Herschel/SPIRE imaging and therefore extract robust far-infrared fluxes for these sources. The far-infrared luminosities of these four sources therefore range from L_FIR ~ 4-7 X 10^12 L_sol, implying CO luminosities of L_CO ~ 2-4 X 10^10 K km/s pc^2. Using the relation L_CO = 3.25 X 10^7*S_CO*delta(v)*D^2*nu^-2*(1+z)^3 (Solomon et al. 1997), this translates into S_CO*delta(v) ~ 0.6-1.2 Jy km/s, or S_CO ~ 1.2-2.4 mJy assuming a typical CO(3-2) line width (FWHM) of 500 km/s. These values are in line with typical values measured for SMGs (Bothwell et al. 2012).

Given the significant uncertainties in all of these estimates (for example, fixing the dust emissivity to beta=2, as proposed by Magnelli et al., would more than double the predicted CO flux for some sources), we choose to retain a constant noise limit over all four targets. We therefore estimate an on-source exposure time of ~28 min per target. Including the current Cycle 2 calibrations and overheads, this becomes ~60 min per target, or ~4 hours total for all four SMGs.
Even in these relatively short exposures, we expect to obtain high-significance detections of the CO(3-2) emission from these luminous SMGs (~20sigma integrated over the line). Given our requested resolution, we expect to resolve the sources over ~4-5 beams, resulting in ~4-5sigma detections per beam. This combination of resolution and S/N will allow us to identify spatial offsets down to </~1 kpc scales between distinct velocity components within these systems.
We also expect to obtain ~8sigma detections of the rest-frame ~870um continuum in these sources, which, in combination with the existing Band 7 continuum and proposed Band 8/9 continuum, will allow us to better constrain the slope of the long-wavelength spectral energy distribution (and hence the contribution from cold dust).

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CO(3-2) in ALESS 122.1
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Observe CO(3-2) in the z~2 SMG ALESS 122.1

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
From our entire sample of >100 ALMA-identified, spectroscopically-observed SMGs, we have identified exactly four sources which have redshifts that allow them to be observed both in low-J CO and [CII] with ALMA. Because the sources have all been precisely-located with ALMA in Cycle 0, we can be sure that the counterparts are correct. This is critical, as our Cycle 0 program demonstrated that a large fraction of single-dish SMG counterparts identified as 'reliable' by statistical associations are actually incorrect (Hodge et al. 2013a).
The robust spectroscopic redshifts of our sources place them at z~2 and z~3, concurrent with the epoch of galaxy assembly and the peak era of activity for obscured starbursts. All four sources will have their CO(3-2) emission (345 GHz rest-frame) redshifted into Band 3. Using the most extended Cycle 2 configuration (C34-7), we reach an angular resolution of ~0.45", allowing us to resolve the molecular gas reservoirs on scales of ~3 kpc (Fig 3).
For the z~2 sources, we observe the CO(3-2) in the upper sideband, setting up three additional basebands to observe the continuum. The sources require different tunings which we have placed in separate science goals. We use the lowest-resolution FDM mode and average over 8 channels to maintain adequate resolution while keeping the data rate reasonable.
To estimate the required sensitivity for the sources, we use the latest L_FIR-L_CO relation from Bothwell et al. (2012). The relation has some scatter, partly due to the fact that different high-redshift galaxies have been observed at different transitions, and partly inherent to the nature of the individual galaxies. Swinbank et al. (2013) recently used our Cycle 0 870um data, along with 24um and radio imaging, to deblend the Herschel/SPIRE imaging and therefore extract robust far-infrared fluxes for these sources. The far-infrared luminosities of these four sources therefore range from L_FIR ~ 4-7 X 10^12 L_sol, implying CO luminosities of L_CO ~ 2-4 X 10^10 K km/s pc^2. Using the relation L_CO = 3.25 X 10^7*S_CO*delta(v)*D^2*nu^-2*(1+z)^3 (Solomon et al. 1997), this translates into S_CO*delta(v) ~ 0.6-1.2 Jy km/s, or S_CO ~ 1.2-2.4 mJy assuming a typical CO(3-2) line width (FWHM) of 500 km/s. These values are in line with typical values measured for SMGs (Bothwell et al. 2012).
With 50 MHz channels (~125 km/s, sufficient to better-than-Nyquist sample the line), we aim for an average S/N of at least 5sigma per channel in order to well-determine the line profile and so set our sensitivity limit as 0.23 mJy based on the weakest source in our sample. Given the significant uncertainties in all of these estimates (for example, fixing the dust emissivity to beta=2, as proposed by Magnelli et al., would more than double the predicted CO flux for some sources), we choose to retain a constant noise limit over all four targets. We therefore estimate an on-source exposure time of ~28 min per target. Including the current Cycle 2 calibrations and overheads, this becomes ~60 min per target, or ~4 hours total for all four SMGs.
Even in these relatively short exposures, we expect to obtain high-significance detections of the CO(3-2) emission from these luminous SMGs (~20sigma integrated over the line). Given our requested resolution, we expect to resolve the sources over ~4-5 beams, resulting in ~4-5sigma detections per beam. This combination of resolution and S/N will allow us to identify spatial offsets down to </~1 kpc scales between distinct velocity components within these systems.
We also expect to obtain ~8sigma detections of the rest-frame ~870um continuum in these sources, which, in combination with the existing Band 7 continuum and proposed Band 8/9 continuum, will allow us to better constrain the slope of the long-wavelength spectral energy distribution (and hence the contribution from cold dust).

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: C+ at z~3 (Band 8)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Observe C+ in 2 SMGs (ALESS 49.1, 57.1) at z~3

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The [CII]158um emission will be redshifted to Band 8 for the z~3 sources in our sample. We will observe the C+ in the lower sideband so as to place the upper sideband in a cleaner atmospheric window. We set up three additional basebands to observe the continuum. The sources are sufficiently close in redshift that we use only one tuning. We use the lowest-resolution FDM mode and average over 8 channels to maintain adequate resolution while keeping the data rate reasonable.
To estimate the required sensitivity for the sources, we use the latest L_[CII]/L_FIR ratios measured for z~4 ALESS SMGs by Swinbank et al. (2012), who reported ratios between R=0.07-0.16%. Swinbank et al. (2013) recently used our Cycle 0 870um data, along with 24um and radio imaging, to deblend the Herschel/SPIRE imaging and therefore extract robust far-infrared fluxes for these sources. The far-infrared luminosities of our Band 8 sources range from L_FIR ~ 4-7 X 10^12 L_sol, therefore implying [CII] luminosities of L_[CII] ~ 3-5 X 10^9 L_sol assuming R=0.7%. This translates into S_[CII]*delta(v) ~ 10-15 Jy km/s, or S_[CII] ~ 20-30 mJy assuming a line width (FWHM) of 500 km/s (Swinbank et al. 2012).
With 200 MHz channels (~125 km/s, sufficient to better-than-Nyquist sample the line), we aim for an average S/N of at least 5sigma per channel in order to well-determine the line profile. In order to also obtain a significant (>5sigma/beam) detection of the (resolved) continuum, we set our sensitivity limit to 1.6 mJy based on the weakest source. Given the significant uncertainties in all of these estimates (for example, assuming a L_[CII]/L_FIR ratio of 0.24% instead, as found in De Breuck et al. 2011, would more than double the [CII] flux), we choose to retain a constant noise limit over our targets. We therefore estimate an on-source exposure time of ~10 min per target. Including the current Cycle 2 calibrations and overheads, this becomes ~30 min per target, or ~1 hour total for the two Band 8 SMGs.
Even in these relatively short exposures, we expect to obtain high-significance detections of the [CII] emission from these luminous SMGs (~20sigma integrated over the line). Given our requested resolution (0.45" with C34-3; Fig. 3), we expect to resolve the sources over ~4-5 beams, resulting in ~4-5sigma detections per beam. This combination of resolution and S/N will allow us to identify spatial offsets down to </~1 kpc scales between distinct velocity components within these systems.
We also expect to obtain ~30 sigma detections of the restframe ~158um continuum in these sources (or ~5-8 sigma per beam), which, in combination with the existing Band 7 continuum and proposed Band 3 continuum, will allow us to better constrain the slope of the long-wavelength spectral energy distribution (and hence the contribution from cold dust) and (critically) to relate the distribution of this cold dust component to the warmer star-forming gas within these galaxies.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: C+ at z~2 (Band 9)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Observe C+ in 2 SMGs (ALESS 67.1, 122.1) at z~2

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The [CII]158um emission will be redshifted to Band 9 for the z~2 sources in our sample. The sources are sufficiently close in redshift that we use only one tuning. We will observe the C+ in the lower sideband (for 67.1) and upper sideband (for 122.1), carefully placing the basebands to avoid the strong atmospheric feature at ~620 GHz.
To estimate the required sensitivity for the sources, we use the latest L_[CII]/L_FIR ratios measured for z~4 ALESS SMGs by Swinbank et al. (2012), who reported ratios between 0.07-0.16%. Swinbank et al. (2013) recently used our Cycle 0 870um data, along with 24um and radio imaging, to deblend the Herschel/SPIRE imaging and therefore extract robust far-infrared fluxes for these sources. The far-infrared luminosities of our Band 9 sources range from L_FIR ~ 5-6 X 10^12 L_sol, therefore implying [CII] luminosities of L_[CII] ~ 3.5-4.5 X 10^9 L_sol. This translates into S_[CII]*delta(v) ~ 20-25 Jy km/s, or S_[CII] ~ 40-50 mJy assuming a line width (FWHM) of 500 km/s (Swinbank et al. 2012).
With 250 MHz channels (~125 km/s, sufficient to better-than-Nyquist sample the line), we aim for an average S/N of at least 5sigma per channel in order to well-determine the line profile. In order to also obtain a significant (>5sigma/beam) detection of the (resolved) continuum, we set our sensitivity limit as 4.5 mJy based on the weakest source. Given the significant uncertainties in all of these estimates (for example, assuming a L_[CII]/L_FIR ratio of 0.24% instead, as found in De Breuck et al. 2011, would more than double the [CII] flux), we choose to retain a constant noise limit over our targets. We therefore estimate an on-source exposure time of ~14 min per target. Including the current Cycle 2 calibrations and overheads, this becomes ~40 min per target, or 1.3 hours total for the two Band 9 SMGs.
Even in these relatively short exposures, we expect to obtain high-significance detections of the [CII] emission from these luminous SMGs (~20sigma integrated over the line). Given our requested resolution (0.45" with C34-2; Fig. 3), we expect to resolve the sources over ~4-5 beams, resulting in ~4-5sigma detections per beam. This combination of resolution and S/N will allow us to identify spatial offsets down to </~1 kpc scales between distinct velocity components within these systems.
We also expect to obtain ~25 sigma detections of the restframe ~158um continuum in these sources (or ~5-6 sigma per beam), which, in combination with the existing Band 7 continuum and proposed Band 3 continuum, will allow us to better constrain the slope of the long-wavelength spectral energy distribution (and hence the contribution from cold dust) and (critically) to relate the distribution of this cold dust component to the warmer star-forming gas within these galaxies.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose resolved (0.45), matched-resolution mapping of the CO, [CII], and underlying dust continuum in a carefully selected sample of z~2-3 galaxies in the ECDFS. The proposed targets were drawn from our Cycle 0 870um survey of >100 sub-mm galaxies (SMGs), the largest, most homogenous, and best-studied sample of interferometrically observed SMGs to date. Our recently completed spectroscopic follow-up campaign has allowed us to meticulously identify 4 SMGs with redshifts that allow us to observe both low-J CO and [CII] with ALMA. In addition to providing tight constraints on gas masses, SF efficiencies, kinematics, and PDR models, these observations will reveal the fundamental relationship between molecular gas and star formation (`Kennicutt-Schmidt law') on ~kpc scales. Critically, they will also allow us to test how well [CII] correlates with the cold molecular gas reservoir probed with CO. This is imperative, as [CII] will be the main line for studying the star-forming ISM at even higher-z. These detailed case studies, which are only now becoming possible with ALMA, are an essential complement to larger statistical studies of individual tracers and integrated properties.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: #2011.1.00294.S: "More than LESS: The first fully-identified submillimetre survey" (PI: Smail) #2012.1.00307.S: "Resolved, direct imaging of the obscured star forming regions in SMGs (PI: Hodge)
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
